Millions of visitors flock to the park each year, waiting for a glimpse of the diverse wildlife.

abstract: With a ghostly finger in a lab, researchers coaxed people to hear phantom voices.
snippet: With a ghostly finger in a lab, researchers coaxed people to hear phantom voices.
lead_paragraph: Some years ago, scientists in Switzerland found a way to make people hallucinate. They didn't use LSD or sensory deprivation chambers. Instead, they sat people in a chair and asked them to push a button that, a fraction of a second later, caused a rod to gently press their back. After a few rounds, the volunteers got the creeping sense of someone behind them. Faced with a disconnect between their actions and their sensations, their minds conjured another explanation: a separate presence in the room.

headline.main: If You've Ever Heard a Voice That Wasn't There, This Could Be Why
headline.print_headline: Do You Hear What I Hear?

abstract: Researchers identified some 3,300 types of brain cells, an order of magnitude more than was previously known, and have only a dim notion of what most of them do.
snippet: Researchers identified some 3,300 types of brain cells, an order of magnitude more than was previously known, and have only a dim notion of what most of them do.
lead_paragraph: An international team of scientists has mapped the human brain in much finer resolution than ever before. The brain atlas, a $375 million effort started in 2017, has identified more than 3,300 types of brain cells, an order of magnitude more than was previously reported. The researchers have only a dim notion of what the newly discovered cells do.

headline.main: The Human Brain Has a Dizzying Array of Mystery Cells

abstract: For a series on the health threats posed by mosquitoes, a Times reporter followed the insects into drainage pipes, bedrooms and the rainforest.
snippet: For a series on the health threats posed by mosquitoes, a Times reporter followed the insects into drainage pipes, bedrooms and the rainforest.
lead_paragraph: In one corner of the low-roofed shed, a cluster of mosquitoes, most likely carrying malaria, rested on a wall. In the opposite corner, a herd of goats — who seemed displeased to see me — huddled together. I crouched on the dirt between the two parties, trying to offend neither, taking notes.

headline.main: Crossing Swamps and Sieving Sewage: A Year of Reporting on Mosquitoes
headline.print_headline: A Year With Mosquitoes, From Labs to Swamps

abstract: Following up a on study in 2021 of tracks found in New Mexico, researchers used more methods to bolster the claim that the tracks are up to 23,000 years old.
snippet: Following up a on study in 2021 of tracks found in New Mexico, researchers used more methods to bolster the claim that the tracks are up to 23,000 years old.
lead_paragraph: Hidden within the seemingly barren expanse of White Sands National Park in New Mexico are human footprints. But these impressions are much more than random tracks: They are ancient vignettes cast in gypsum-rich sand. The footprints tell stories of hunters stalking a giant sloth; a traveler slipping in mud with a child on one hip; children jumping in puddles, splashing in play; and more.

headline.main: New Evidence That Ancient Footprints Push Back Human Arrival in North America
headline.print_headline: The Sands of Time: New Tests on Footprints Bolster Claims About Humans' Arrival in North America

abstract: When confronted with recordings of human voices, 19 species fled instantly, while they were less frightened by lion sounds and other potentially threatening recordings.
snippet: When confronted with recordings of human voices, 19 species fled instantly, while they were less frightened by lion sounds and other potentially threatening recordings.
lead_paragraph: Panting after chasing the impala now in its jaws, a leopard drags its prey to a shady spot beside a water hole. Before it can sit down to feast, a voice, seemingly out of nowhere, begins speaking calmly. “It is very difficult to talk in Afrikaans …,” begins the bodiless voice. The leopard pauses, glances toward the source of the sound and then drops its hard-earned quarry and runs.

headline.main: Watch How Animals React to the Scariest Sound on the Savanna
headline.print_headline: The Scariest Sound on the Savanna? Your Voice.

snippet: Researchers completed a complex simulation that supports the idea that the giant planet's jewelry emerged hundreds of millions of years ago, not billions.
lead_paragraph: Try to imagine Saturn without its signature rings. Now picture two large icy moons shifting closer together little by little until — boom. Chaos. What was solid is now fluid. Diamantine shards scatter into the darkness. Many icy fragments tumble close to Saturn, remain there and dance around the gas giant in unison, ultimately forging the heavyweight body's exquisite discs.

headline.main: Saturn's Rings May Have Formed in a Surprisingly Recent Crash of 2 Moons
headline.print_headline: Lore of the Ring: Saturn's Most Distinctive Feature May Have Formed in a Collision

abstract: Researchers at the National Ignition Facility during a July firing of 192 lasers improved on a December result, but also ended up with duds in other experiments.
snippet: Researchers at the National Ignition Facility during a July firing of 192 lasers improved on a December result, but also ended up with duds in other experiments.
lead_paragraph: In July, scientists at the National Ignition Facility at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California generated a burst of energy by bombarding a pellet of hydrogen with 192 lasers, reproducing for a brief moment the process of fusion that powers the sun. It was a repeat of an experiment last December, but this time the scientists generated even more energy with nearly a factor of two in gain compared with the energy of the incoming lasers.

headline.main: A Laser Fusion Breakthrough Gets a Bigger Burst of Energy
headline.print_headline: Fusion Leap: Lasers Ignite Bigger Burst Of Energy

abstract: Researchers believed there were eight species of the strange mammals. But a ninth was identified genetically, although no one knew it was a separate species in the wild.
snippet: Researchers believed there were eight species of the strange mammals. But a ninth was identified genetically, although no one knew it was a separate species in the wild.
lead_paragraph: The pangolin is an absurd animal, a mammal that's dressed up as a reptile with a coat of scales, sharp claws and sticky saliva. Wildlife experts often say they are the most trafficked mammals in the world as poachers target pangolins for their meat and their scales, which are used in traditional medicines. There are eight species, all under various levels of threat.

headline.main: A Mystery Species Was Discovered in Trafficked Pangolin Scales

abstract: Because box jellyfish are so distantly related to other animals, the research findings could hint at how the ability to learn first evolved.
snippet: Because box jellyfish are so distantly related to other animals, the research findings could hint at how the ability to learn first evolved.
lead_paragraph: In the dappled sunlit waters of Caribbean mangrove forests, tiny box jellyfish bob in and out of the shade. Box jellies are distinguished from true jellyfish in part by their complex visual system — the grape-size predators have 24 eyes. But like other jellyfish, they are brainless, controlling their cube-shaped bodies with a distributed network of neurons.

headline.main: Brainless Jellyfish Demonstrate Learning Ability
headline.print_headline: Educated JellyFish: It's Brainless, Sure,  But Not Exactly Dimwitted

abstract: This year's awards were given to scientists who helped doctors see the retina and used artificial intelligence to predict the shapes of cellular proteins.
snippet: This year's awards were given to scientists who helped doctors see the retina and used artificial intelligence to predict the shapes of cellular proteins.
lead_paragraph: The prestigious Lasker Awards were given on Thursday to scientists making advances in the diagnosis of eye disease, the prediction of cellular protein structure and the intricacies of the immune system. The awards, closely watched by researchers in biomedical fields, often foreshadow Nobel Prizes.

headline.main: Advances in Eye Scans and Protein Structure Win 2023 Lasker Awards

abstract: In experiments under his microscope at home, a teenage researcher discovered a very unusual talent in a species of tiny insect that usually lays eggs on the inside of a tough plant growth.
snippet: In experiments under his microscope at home, a teenage researcher discovered a very unusual talent in a species of tiny insect that usually lays eggs on the inside of a tough plant growth.
lead_paragraph: By the time Matvey Nikelshparg was 13, he was obsessed with parasitoid wasps, tiny insects that lay their eggs on or inside other bugs. Under a microscope in a lab he had assembled at home, he discovered that one species had a startling superpower: It could use an organ that protrudes from its abdomen to drill through a plastic petri dish.

headline.main: This Tiny Parasitic Wasp Can Drill Through Plastic
headline.print_headline: Drilling Down: To Uncover Wasp's Superpower, Teen Thinks Outside the Petri Dish

snippet: Scientists have unearthed logs in Africa that are nearly a half-million years old, the remnants of large wooden structures crafted by our early ancestors.

headline.main: Ancient Logs Offer Earliest Example of Human Woodworking

snippet: Researchers propose that placozoans, one of the simplest kinds of animals, may contain the blueprint for the neurons of more complex creatures.
lead_paragraph: For hundreds of millions of years, pancake-shaped animals about the size of a sharp pencil tip have been roving the seas with an appetite for tasty microbes and algae. They're called placozoans, and are among the simplest of the major animal lineages.

snippet: Researchers discovered that a particular brand of paint favored by the Spanish artist had an atomic structure that predisposed it to degradation.
lead_paragraph: From Van Gogh's sunflowers to Edvard Munch's “The Scream,” there's no shortage of seminal artwork that was made with a striking hue known as cadmium yellow. But that riot of color that artists squeezed from their paint tubes isn't necessarily what museum goers see today: cadmium yellow's brilliance often diminishes over time, as the paint fades and turns chalky.

headline.main: Why Miró's Yellows Have Lost Their Brilliance
headline.print_headline: Fading Miros: Why a Painter's Yellows  Aren't So Yellow Anymore

abstract: In a new report, scientists offer a list of measurable qualities that might indicate the presence of some presence in a machine.
snippet: In a new report, scientists offer a list of measurable qualities that might indicate the presence of some presence in a machine.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever talked to someone who is “into consciousness?” How did that conversation go? Did they make a vague gesture in the air with both hands? Did they reference the Tao Te Ching or Jean-Paul Sartre? Did they say that, actually, there's nothing scientists can be sure about, and that reality is only as real as we make it out to be?

headline.main: How to Tell if Your A.I. Is Conscious
headline.print_headline: Is Your A.I. Conscious? Follow This Checklist.

lead_paragraph: When a mountain-size slab of space rock rammed into the Yucatán Peninsula 66 million years ago, the fallout was apocalyptic. Roughly three-fourths of the planet's species, most notably non-avian dinosaurs, were wiped out.

lead_paragraph: Enceladus — the sixth-largest of Saturn's 146 moons — has a liquid ocean with a rocky floor under its bright, white and frosty surface. Ice volcanoes spew frozen grains of material into space, generating one of the many rings circling the planet.

headline.main: A ‘Soda Ocean' on a Moon of Saturn Has All the Ingredients for Life
headline.print_headline: Ocean on Moon of Saturn Has Ingredients for Life

abstract: The snaggletoothed cetacean used teeth projected from its snout to stun prey, much like modern sawfish do.
snippet: The snaggletoothed cetacean used teeth projected from its snout to stun prey, much like modern sawfish do.
lead_paragraph: The waters off New Zealand 25 million years ago were home to early baleen whales, megatooth sharks and human-size penguins. Now researchers are adding a bizarre dolphin to the mix that may have used tusklike teeth to thrash prey into submission.

headline.main: This Extinct Dolphin Had Tusks That Fish Were Wise to Avoid
headline.print_headline: Ancient Slasher: This Dolphin Had Teeth Only a Dentist Could Love

snippet: The change is part of a broader push in several countries to limit gender-related medical treatments for young people.

abstract: Taurine helped stave off death in laboratory animals, but researchers cautioned that the supplement is not a magic elixir.
snippet: Taurine helped stave off death in laboratory animals, but researchers cautioned that the supplement is not a magic elixir.
lead_paragraph: A dietary supplement taken by fitness buffs could hold the key to a longer and healthier life, suggests a new study of mice, monkeys and worms. Researchers found that a high daily dose of taurine, an amino acid commonly added to energy drinks and naturally found in various foods, helped to delay death and mitigate against the biological ravages of aging.

headline.main: From Energy Drinks to Extending Life? Supplement Slows Aging in Mice and Monkeys
headline.print_headline: . . . But a Small Study Suggests An Ingredient Can Slow Aging

abstract: In Argentina, kelp gulls are attacking the backs of southern right whales, imperiling the recovery of an endangered species.
snippet: In Argentina, kelp gulls are attacking the backs of southern right whales, imperiling the recovery of an endangered species.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of colossal southern right whales travel to the calm waters of Península Valdés off the coast of Argentina each year to breed and give birth. The cetaceans, which can reach 56 feet in length, are a sight to behold, especially with their calves in tow. But if you venture out to see them, you may sometimes find your stomach turning for a reason that has nothing to do with sea sickness.

headline.main: Birds With a Taste for Flesh Threaten Whale Calves
headline.print_headline: Ghoulish Gulls: Seabirds With a Taste for Flesh  Threaten Southern Right Whale Calves

headline.main: Scientists Discover a Virgin Birth in a Crocodile

lead_paragraph: A century ago, archaeologists excavated a 3,300-year-old Egyptian palace in Amarna, which was fleetingly the capital of Egypt during the reign of the pharaoh Akhenaten. Situated far from the crowded areas of Amarna, the North Palace offered a quiet retreat for the royal family.

headline.main: Put a Bird on It? Ancient Egypt Was Way Ahead of Us.

abstract: A large “de-escalation” trial suggests that tens of thousands of people annually may be able to rely on only chemotherapy and surgery to treat their illness.
snippet: A large “de-escalation” trial suggests that tens of thousands of people annually may be able to rely on only chemotherapy and surgery to treat their illness.

headline.main: Rectal Cancer Patients Could Be Spared the Effects of Radiation
headline.print_headline: Rectal Cancer Patients  May No Longer Need To Undergo Radiation

abstract: The H5N1 virus poses “a great unknown threat” to birds and humans alike. Understanding and thwarting it begins with excrement collection.
snippet: The H5N1 virus poses “a great unknown threat” to birds and humans alike. Understanding and thwarting it begins with excrement collection.
lead_paragraph: It was a glorious day for field work on the shores of the Delaware Bay. The late afternoon sun cast a warm glow over the gently sloping beach. The receding tide revealed a smattering of shells. The dune grasses rustled in the breeze. The beach vines were in bloom. And the bird droppings were fresh and plentiful.

headline.main: For These Bird Flu Researchers, Work Is a Day at the Very ‘Icky' Beach
headline.print_headline: Bird Flu Research Can Be a Day at an ‘Icky' Beach

snippet: Death investigators in Utah are among a handful of groups trying to learn how many gay and transgender people die by suicide in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Cory Russo, the chief death investigator in Utah, is used to asking strangers questions at the most excruciating moments of their lives. When she shows up at the scene of a suicide, a homicide or another type of unexpected death, her job is to interview the grievers about how the deceased had lived.

headline.main: No One Knows How Many L.G.B.T.Q. Americans Die by Suicide
headline.print_headline: Utah Is Driving Push to Fill Void on L.G.B.T.Q. Suicide Data

abstract: Scientists were able to unlock the identity of an ichthyosaur that had been reduced to a two-dimension jumble of bones.
snippet: Scientists were able to unlock the identity of an ichthyosaur that had been reduced to a two-dimension jumble of bones.
lead_paragraph: While exploring an Arctic mountaintop in 2008, paleontologists unearthed a small skeleton that resembled a coiled sea serpent imprinted into a slab of 240 million-year-old rock. The remarkably complete skeleton, nicknamed Oda, was deposited in the collection of the University of Oslo's Natural History Museum.

headline.main: X-Ray Vision Brings New Life to a Fossil Flattened by Time
headline.print_headline: A Clearer View: X-Ray Vision Uncovers Identity of Fossil Flattened by Time

snippet: Mortality rates fell by 20 percent among women in countries that began cash transfer programs to the poor. Children also benefited.
lead_paragraph: Cash grants made directly to poor families or individuals have led to fewer deaths among women and young children, according to a new analysis of more than 7 million people in 37 countries.

headline.main: How to Lower Deaths Among Women? Give Away Cash.
headline.print_headline: How to Cut Death Rates For Women? Give Cash.

abstract: Polygenic risk scores could help patients, including younger ones, understand whether they really need early treatment for heart disease.
snippet: Polygenic risk scores could help patients, including younger ones, understand whether they really need early treatment for heart disease.
lead_paragraph: Katie Elkins has a family history of heart disease on both sides of the family, and she was worried. Her father had a heart attack this year on Easter morning at the age of 53 — the same age his mother was when she had one.

headline.main: To Prevent Heart Attacks, Doctors Try a New Genetic Test
headline.print_headline: Too Soon for Heart Drugs?

abstract: After a successful mission to Mars, the Emirati space agency is planning a tour of the debris field between Mars and Jupiter, with a focus on one of its most intriguing objects.
snippet: After a successful mission to Mars, the Emirati space agency is planning a tour of the debris field between Mars and Jupiter, with a focus on one of its most intriguing objects.
lead_paragraph: Building off the success of its Hope spacecraft, which is still circling and studying Mars, the United Arab Emirates announced on Monday plans for an ambitious follow-up mission: a grand tour of the asteroid belt.

headline.main: The United Arab Emirates Is Heading for the Asteroid Belt
headline.print_headline: On Heels of Mars Success, U.A.E. Eyes the Asteroid Belt

abstract: Recent research shows that most pregnancy-related deaths occur in the year after a baby is born. The discovery is changing how doctors care for new mothers.
snippet: Recent research shows that most pregnancy-related deaths occur in the year after a baby is born. The discovery is changing how doctors care for new mothers.
lead_paragraph: Sherri Willis-Prater's baby boy was 2 months old, and she was about to return to her job at a school cafeteria in Chicago. But as she walked up the short flight of stairs to her kitchen one evening, she nearly collapsed, gasping for breath.

headline.main: Maternity's Most Dangerous Time: After New Mothers Come Home
headline.print_headline: Risk to Mothers Lasts a Full Year After Childbirth

abstract: New mothers are at risk for up to a year, research has shown. But the first six weeks are the most perilous.
snippet: New mothers are at risk for up to a year, research has shown. But the first six weeks are the most perilous.
lead_paragraph: After a woman gives birth, the baby's well-being usually becomes the focus of family attention, and the mother's health often recedes as a priority. Many busy new mothers don't make it to their postpartum visit with an obstetrician or midwife, even though recent medical guidelines say they should do so within three weeks of the delivery.

headline.main: Complications After Delivery: What Women Need to Know

abstract: In a study that has yet to be peer-reviewed, scientists documented behavior in a captive cephalopod that they say looks very similar to a bad dream.
snippet: In a study that has yet to be peer-reviewed, scientists documented behavior in a captive cephalopod that they say looks very similar to a bad dream.
lead_paragraph: Costello the octopus was napping while stuck to the glass of his tank at the Rockefeller University in New York. He snoozed quietly for half an hour, and then entered a more active sleep stage, his skin cycling through colors and textures used for camouflage — typical behavior for a cephalopod.

headline.main: Is This Octopus Having a Nightmare?
headline.print_headline: Jumpy Cephalopods: Studying a Snoozing Octopus, And Encountering a Nightmare

abstract: Experiments offer an intriguing hint at technology that could induce torpor in humans in the future.
snippet: Experiments offer an intriguing hint at technology that could induce torpor in humans in the future.
lead_paragraph: For many animals, life is a cycle of scarcity as well as plenty. Hibernating creatures curl up underground in winter, slowing their metabolism so they can make it to spring without food. Even laboratory mice, if deprived of food, can enter a state called torpor, a kind of standby mode that economizes energy.

headline.main: Ultrasound Pulses to Brain Send Mice Into a Hibernation-Like State
headline.print_headline: Slow-Motion Rodents: Can't Wait for Suspended Animation? Maybe Mice Could Speed Things Up.

abstract: Researchers just discovered that the spiny mouse was concealing bony plates beneath the skin over its tail.
snippet: Researchers just discovered that the spiny mouse was concealing bony plates beneath the skin over its tail.
lead_paragraph: At first it looks like a slightly more hairy rodent. But the spiny mouse's body is full of secrets. Found in rock outcrops throughout Africa and Europe, its back is full of porcupine-like quills made of stiffened fur. It has soft, easily torn skin and a remarkable ability to regenerate, like a species of desert gecko. Now, researchers have revealed another surprise in the journal iScience on Wednesday: Their tails are lined with osteoderms, or bony plates, making them only the second group of living mammals known to be equipped with underskin armor like an armadillo.

headline.main: Quite a Tail: A Mouse Has Been Hiding Its Armor All This Time
headline.print_headline: Deceptive Rodent: All This Time, a Mouse Has Been Hiding Its Armor

abstract: Using CT scanning on 16th-century books, researchers uncovered bits of parchment salvaged from handwritten manuscripts.
snippet: Using CT scanning on 16th-century books, researchers uncovered bits of parchment salvaged from handwritten manuscripts.
lead_paragraph: Even in medieval times, recycling was in vogue: Bits of parchment salvaged from older handwritten manuscripts were often used to reinforce other books. Using CT scanning, a team of researchers has now shown that those medieval leftovers hidden beneath some books' covers can be seen. Studying these medieval binding fragments can help reveal how, when and where early books were assembled, and there's always the tantalizing possibility of finding a previously unknown manuscript.

headline.main: A Hospital Visit Reveals Medieval Secrets Hidden in Books
headline.print_headline: Hidden History: Using Modern Medical Technology To Unlock Secrets in Medieval Books

abstract: Four decades ago, medical researchers reached out to ailing families in Colombia for insights into Huntington's disease. Scientists are just now following up, hoping it's not too late.
snippet: Four decades ago, medical researchers reached out to ailing families in Colombia for insights into Huntington's disease. Scientists are just now following up, hoping it's not too late.
lead_paragraph: José Echeverría spends restless days in a metal chair reinforced with boards and padded with a piece of foam that his mother, Nohora Vásquez, adjusts constantly for his comfort. The chair is coming loose and will soon fall apart. Huntington's disease, which causes José to move his head and limbs uncontrollably, has already left one bed frame destroyed. At 42, he is still strong.

headline.main: Sought Out by Science, and Then Forgotten
headline.print_headline: The Forgotten

byline.original: By Jennie Erin Smith and Charlie Cordero

abstract: A new study linked chronic pain to activity in the orbitofrontal cortex, an area involved in emotion regulation, self-evaluation and decision making.
snippet: A new study linked chronic pain to activity in the orbitofrontal cortex, an area involved in emotion regulation, self-evaluation and decision making.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have for the first time recorded the brain's firing patterns while a person is feeling chronic pain, paving the way for implanted devices to one day predict pain signals or even short-circuit them.

headline.main: Scientists Find Brain Signals of Chronic Pain

abstract: As an extinction crisis wiped out species at the end of the Permian Period, a predatory species emerged that dominated Southern Africa's domain.
snippet: As an extinction crisis wiped out species at the end of the Permian Period, a predatory species emerged that dominated Southern Africa's domain.
lead_paragraph: Some 252 million years ago, it was a disastrous time to be alive. Erupting supervolcanoes destabilized ecosystems, plunging the planet's living things into a series of extinctions over the course of a million years and permanently changing life on Earth.

abstract: Joro spiders are spreading around the United States and may turn up in New York soon. Recent experiments suggest that they may be shyer than other arachnids.

lead_paragraph: Joro spiders are the size of your palm. They weave webs up to three feet across, and for the past decade, the East Asian arachnids have been spreading throughout the southeastern United States.

abstract: It's not because they make us sad but because they help us feel connected, a new study suggests.
snippet: It's not because they make us sad but because they help us feel connected, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: When Joshua Knobe was younger, he knew an indie rock musician who sang sorrowful, “heart-rending things that made people feel terrible,” he recalled recently. At one point he came across a YouTube video, set to her music, that had a suicidal motif. “That was the theme of her music,” he said, adding, “So I had this sense of puzzlement by it, because I also felt like it had this tremendous value.”

headline.main: The Reason People Listen to Sad Songs
headline.print_headline: Sad Songs Say So Much  About Connection

headline.print_headline: Jynneos Jab Is Effective On Mpox, Studies Say

lead_paragraph: Massive prehistoric stone structures found in desert landscapes from Saudi Arabia to Kazakhstan have baffled archaeologists for decades. Each can stretch for up to a few miles, and resembles a kite with tail strings in overall shape.

lead_paragraph: Siler collingwoodi is a spider that jumps and wears a coat of vibrant and metallic blues, oranges and sometimes reds. It also does impressions, copying the movements of an assortment of ant species.

snippet: A new study bolsters the idea that the first animals were surprisingly complex, perhaps equipped with muscles and a nervous system.
lead_paragraph: One of the greatest transformations in the history of life occurred more than 600 million years ago, when a single-celled organism gave rise to the first animals. With their multicellular bodies, animals evolved into a staggering range of forms, like whales that weigh 200 tons, birds that soar six miles into the sky and sidewinders that slither across desert dunes.

headline.main: Bizarre Sea Creatures Illuminate the Dawn of the Animal Kingdom

snippet: A new genetic analysis of 290 people suggests that humans emerged at various times and places in Africa.

abstract: A man in his early 40s showed physical signs of the illness, but didn't develop symptoms until he was nearly 70 because of a protective gene.
snippet: A man in his early 40s showed physical signs of the illness, but didn't develop symptoms until he was nearly 70 because of a protective gene.
lead_paragraph: The man should have gotten Alzheimer's disease in his early 40s — he had a gene mutation that guaranteed it, or so it seemed. Scans of his brain even revealed severe atrophying and the hallmarks of the disease: rough, hard, amyloid plaques and spaghetti-like tangles of tau proteins. But the fatal brain disease did not appear until the man was 67.

headline.main: Mutation Protected Man From Alzheimer's Disease, Hinting at Treatment
headline.print_headline: Alzheimer's Was Delayed By Mutation, Study Finds

abstract: For three years, telescopes have monitored “one of the most luminous” events ever: a supermassive black hole consuming a gigantic cloud of interstellar gas.
snippet: For three years, telescopes have monitored “one of the most luminous” events ever: a supermassive black hole consuming a gigantic cloud of interstellar gas.
lead_paragraph: It's a dog-eat-dog cosmos. Not two weeks ago, on May 3, astronomers reported observing a star that was in the process of swallowing one of its own planets. Just two days earlier, another team had described black holes that were ripping stars apart and consuming them in a process known as tidal disruption event, or T.D.E.

headline.main: The Biggest Explosion in the Cosmos Just Keeps Going
headline.print_headline: Telescopes Capture  A Singular Cosmic Blast

abstract: To survive as they seek food in freezing parts of the ocean, hammerhead sharks use a trick that hasn't been observed in other fish.
snippet: To survive as they seek food in freezing parts of the ocean, hammerhead sharks use a trick that hasn't been observed in other fish.
lead_paragraph: Hammerhead sharks like it warm, but for a good meal they're willing to get cold. The flat-headed predators dive more than 2,600 feet from tropical surface waters into the ocean's frigid depths multiple times every night to hunt for fish and squid, tolerating a 68-degree Fahrenheit plunge in temperature to dine.

headline.print_headline: Deep Divers: Down in the Frigid Depths, These Sharks Hold Their Breaths

abstract: Black patients with opioid use disorder were far less likely to fill prescriptions for the most effective addiction treatments than white patients. But strikingly few patients of all races got the medicine.

lead_paragraph: In a lab in Atlanta, thousands of yeast cells fight for their lives every day. The ones that live another day grow fastest, reproduce quickest and form the biggest clumps. For about a decade, the cells have evolved to hang onto one another, forming branching snowflake shapes.

lead_paragraph: Five years ago, a small group of cancer scientists meeting at a restaurant in a deconsecrated church hospital in Mainz, Germany, drew up an audacious plan: They would test their novel cancer vaccine against one of the most virulent forms of the disease, a cancer notorious for roaring back even in patients whose tumors had been removed.

abstract: The bugs are unique among colony-forming insects in that their queens cannot rule without a king.
snippet: The bugs are unique among colony-forming insects in that their queens cannot rule without a king.
lead_paragraph: While millions of eyes are on the coronation of Charles III this weekend, other male monarchs will carry on ruling in obscurity — literal obscurity, because they live in darkness underground, or maybe in a piece of rotting wood.

headline.main: All Hail the King (of the Termites)
headline.print_headline: All Hail the King (of the Termites)

abstract: Anhingas, water birds with snakelike necks, have turned up in Prospect Park in Brooklyn and far upstate, a sign of shifting ranges for birds from the South.
snippet: Anhingas, water birds with snakelike necks, have turned up in Prospect Park in Brooklyn and far upstate, a sign of shifting ranges for birds from the South.
lead_paragraph: For two weeks, a strange bird has perched in Brooklyn over the treetops of one of the Three Sisters Islands in Prospect Park Lake. It shows no signs of heading back to the place it most likely came from in the South.

headline.main: The ‘Devil Bird' Lands in New York, With More Likely to Come
headline.print_headline: The Devil Bird Lands in New York

abstract: The longer a person's telomeres, researchers found, the greater the risk of cancer and other disorders, challenging a popular hypothesis about the chromosomal roots of vitality.
snippet: The longer a person's telomeres, researchers found, the greater the risk of cancer and other disorders, challenging a popular hypothesis about the chromosomal roots of vitality.
lead_paragraph: The story, as often happens in science, sounded so appealing. Cells have a molecular clock that determines how long they live. If you can just stop the clock, cells can live indefinitely. And the same should go for people, who are, after all, made from cells. Stop the cell clocks and you can remain youthful.

headline.main: Link Between Long Telomeres and Long Life Is a Tall Tale, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Link to a Long Life   Is Only a Tall Tale

abstract: Donanemab is not a cure and comes with significant side effects, but patients had longer periods of independent living while on the drug.
snippet: Donanemab is not a cure and comes with significant side effects, but patients had longer periods of independent living while on the drug.
lead_paragraph: The drug manufacturer Eli Lilly announced on Wednesday that a clinical trial of an experimental Alzheimer's drug showed it can slow progress of the feared disease and allow patients to have more time when they can still live independently, performing tasks like cooking meals, going to the store and driving a car.

headline.main: Eli Lilly Trial Finds Alzheimer's Drug Can Slow Progress of Disease
headline.print_headline: Clinical Trial Finds Alzheimer's Drug Can Slow Its Progress

abstract: Astronomers spotted a dying star swallowing a large planet, a discovery that fills in a “missing link” in understanding the fates of Earth and many other planets.
snippet: Astronomers spotted a dying star swallowing a large planet, a discovery that fills in a “missing link” in understanding the fates of Earth and many other planets.
lead_paragraph: Astronomers have witnessed a star gobbling up a planet, offering the first direct glimpse of a gnarly process called planetary engulfment that most likely awaits Earth in the deep future.

headline.main: It's the End of a World as We Know It
headline.print_headline: Glimpse of a Planet  Being Gobbled Up

abstract: Protection may last even longer, scientists reported. The finding may be a boon to low-income countries, where cervical cancer takes an enormous toll.
snippet: Protection may last even longer, scientists reported. The finding may be a boon to low-income countries, where cervical cancer takes an enormous toll.
lead_paragraph: A single dose of the human papillomavirus vaccine is highly effective at preventing infections over three years, most likely lowering rates of cervical cancer and other diseases linked to the virus, according to a new study in Kenya.

headline.main: One Dose of HPV Vaccine Prevents Infection for at Least Three Years
headline.print_headline: In One Dose, 3 Years of HPV Protection

abstract: In a recent experiment, researchers used large language models to translate brain activity into words.
snippet: In a recent experiment, researchers used large language models to translate brain activity into words.
lead_paragraph: Think of the words whirling around in your head: that tasteless joke you wisely kept to yourself at dinner; your unvoiced impression of your best friend's new partner. Now imagine that someone could listen in.

headline.main: A.I. Is Getting Better at Mind-Reading
headline.print_headline: A.I. to Read Your Mind Is Up Next

abstract: After analyzing genetic data swabbed from a Wuhan market in early 2020, a virologist said it was unclear if animals for sale there had been infected.
snippet: After analyzing genetic data swabbed from a Wuhan market in early 2020, a virologist said it was unclear if animals for sale there had been infected.
lead_paragraph: A new study of genetic data from a market in Wuhan, China, said the data did not support the case that the pandemic had started with illegally traded animals, touching off fresh debate about samples that other scientists see as critical pieces of the puzzle of how the coronavirus reached humans.

headline.main: Scientist Revisits Data on Raccoon Dogs and Covid, Stressing the Unknowns
headline.print_headline: Report Cites Unknowns in Early Covid Spread

abstract: Women's breasts become less dense with age. Cancer may be more likely in breast tissue that is persistently denser over time, a new study suggests.
snippet: Women's breasts become less dense with age. Cancer may be more likely in breast tissue that is persistently denser over time, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have long known that dense breast tissue is linked to an increased risk of breast cancer in women. A study published on Thursday in JAMA Oncology adds a new twist, finding that while breast density declines with age, a slower rate of decline in one breast often precedes a cancer diagnosis in that breast.

headline.main: Researchers Identify Possible New Risk for Breast Cancer
headline.print_headline: Breast Cancer Risk Is Seen When Tissue Stays Denser

abstract: People who spoke two languages daily in their youth tended to score higher on memory tests later in life, the researchers found.
snippet: People who spoke two languages daily in their youth tended to score higher on memory tests later in life, the researchers found.
lead_paragraph: Speaking two languages provides the enviable ability to make friends in unusual places. A new study suggests that bilingualism may also come with another benefit: improved memory in later life.

headline.main: Bilingualism May Stave Off Dementia, Study Suggests
headline.print_headline: Bilingualism May Stave Off Dementia, Study Suggests

abstract: Researchers may have discovered the first example of a frog that pollinates flowering plants.
snippet: Researchers may have discovered the first example of a frog that pollinates flowering plants.
lead_paragraph: On warm evenings near Rio de Janeiro, you might find milk fruit trees covered in brownish-orange frogs. While many frogs eat insects, the tree frog species Xenohyla truncata has a taste for the pulp of bulbous fruits and the nectar in the tree's flowers.

headline.main: Fruitarian Frogs May Be Doing Flowers a Favor
headline.print_headline: Peculiar Pollinators: Fruitarian Frogs Give Flowers a Jump-Start

abstract: Astronomers had already detected one unlikely ring around Quaoar, a small object far beyond Neptune's orbit. Now they have found a second ring.
snippet: Astronomers had already detected one unlikely ring around Quaoar, a small object far beyond Neptune's orbit. Now they have found a second ring.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, astronomers announced that a tiny world beyond Neptune with a diameter about one-third that of Earth's moon possessed a Saturn-like ring that should not be there. It now turns out that there are two such “impossible” rings.

headline.main: Second ‘Impossible' Ring Found Around Distant Dwarf Planet
headline.print_headline: Orbital Surprise: Dwarf Planet Had One ‘Impossible' Ring. Then Astronomers Found Another.

abstract: Over a decade, scientists compared the genomes of 240 mammals to see how humans are the same — and different.
snippet: Over a decade, scientists compared the genomes of 240 mammals to see how humans are the same — and different.
lead_paragraph: It has been 20 years since scientists put together the first rough draft of the human genome, the three billion genetic letters of DNA tightly wound inside most of our cells. Today, scientists are still struggling to decipher it.

headline.main: What Cheetahs, Armadillos and Whales Revealed About Human DNA
headline.print_headline: Exploring What Binds A Family Tree

abstract: A new study offers an alternative to earlier explanations for why moths and other bugs are attracted to artificial sources of illumination.
snippet: A new study offers an alternative to earlier explanations for why moths and other bugs are attracted to artificial sources of illumination.
lead_paragraph: Moths and other insects are drawn to lights at night as reliably as planets orbit stars.

headline.main: Why Are Insects Drawn to Light? A Perennial Question Gets a New Answer.
headline.print_headline: Flaming Out: Why Are Insects Drawn to Light? The Answer Isn't Easy to See.

abstract: Charles Lieber had been seen as a potential Nobel Prize-winning chemist, but was convicted in 2021 of lying to federal investigators and failing to report income.
snippet: Charles Lieber had been seen as a potential Nobel Prize-winning chemist, but was convicted in 2021 of lying to federal investigators and failing to report income.
lead_paragraph: Charles Lieber, a former Harvard chemistry professor, was sentenced on Tuesday for making false statements to the U.S. government and for failing to declare large sums of money he'd been paid as part of a contract with a Chinese program, Thousand Talents, and Wuhan University in China.

headline.main: Ex-Harvard Professor Sentenced in China Ties Case

abstract: Videos of both captive and wild nonhuman primates suggest an enjoyment of the dizzy buzz that comes from whirling in circles.
snippet: Videos of both captive and wild nonhuman primates suggest an enjoyment of the dizzy buzz that comes from whirling in circles.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, a gorilla named Zola gained internet fame when the Calgary Zoo posted a video that showed him spinning in circles on his knuckles and heels with what appeared to be a huge grin on his face. Zola, the so-called break-dancing gorilla, returned in 2017, this time in a video showing him whirling around a kiddie pool with a level of wild enthusiasm rivaling the most committed human dancer at an all-night rave.

headline.main: Why Do Apes Like to Spin? Maybe for the Same Reasons as People.

abstract: Neuroscientists are examining how fish navigate their world using different brain circuits than those relied on by mammals like us.
snippet: Neuroscientists are examining how fish navigate their world using different brain circuits than those relied on by mammals like us.
lead_paragraph: On the one hand, this headgear looks like something a cyberfish would wear. On the other, it's not far from a fashion statement someone at the Kentucky Derby might make.

headline.main: Why Researchers Turned This Goldfish Into a Cyborg
headline.print_headline: You Can Leave Your Hat On: Why Researchers Turned A Goldfish Into a Cyborg

abstract: The American Museum of Natural History is unveiling an enormous new exhibit of leafcutter ants. Making it happen was no picnic.
snippet: The American Museum of Natural History is unveiling an enormous new exhibit of leafcutter ants. Making it happen was no picnic.
lead_paragraph: When the American Museum of Natural History's new insectarium opens on May 4, a half-million leafcutter ants will share the title of star attraction.

headline.main: To Display 500,000 Ants, No Simple Ant Farm Will Do
headline.print_headline: Making 500,000 Ants Feel Right at Home

byline.original: By Emily Anthes and Todd Heisler

abstract: A study suggests that pitcher plants tailor the smells they produce to  woo particular kinds of insects.
snippet: A study suggests that pitcher plants tailor the smells they produce to  woo particular kinds of insects.
lead_paragraph: Pitcher plants supplement their diets with this one strange trick: eating flesh. Usually found growing in relatively poor soil, the plants sprout pitcher-shaped cups with pretty, frilly tops that obscure their true purpose: trapping hapless insects. Look inside the pitchers and you'll find the half-digested bodies of the plants' victims.

headline.main: Carnivorous Plants Use a Smelly Trick to Catch Their Prey
headline.print_headline: Deadly Aroma: This Predator's Secret Weapon? A Perfume With a Punch.

abstract: Scientists let parrots call their parrot friends. Here's what happened.
snippet: Scientists let parrots call their parrot friends. Here's what happened.
lead_paragraph: Scientists let parrots call their parrot friends. Here's what happened.

headline.main: Polly Wants a Video Chat
headline.print_headline: Bird Calls: Sociable Parrots May Want a Video Chat Instead of a Cracker

abstract: During the many months they spend at sea gorging on fish and squid, the massive mammals sleep only about two hours a day.
snippet: During the many months they spend at sea gorging on fish and squid, the massive mammals sleep only about two hours a day.
lead_paragraph: It long seemed as though African elephants were the champions of the all-nighter. They can get by on about two hours of sleep. Other mammals need much more, like koalas (20 hours) or you (at least seven plus at least one strong cup of coffee).

headline.main: Elephant Seals Take Power Naps During Deep Ocean Dives
headline.print_headline: Plenty of Rest on Land, Short Naps Underwater

abstract: Experiments using mice found a malfunction in adult stem cells that offers insights into why we turn into silver foxes and vixens.
snippet: Experiments using mice found a malfunction in adult stem cells that offers insights into why we turn into silver foxes and vixens.
lead_paragraph: Many of the signs of aging are invisible, slow, and subtle — changes in cell division capacity, cardiac output and kidney function don't exactly show up in the mirror. But gray hairs are one of the most obvious clues that the body isn't working like it used to.

headline.main: Your Hair Is Going Gray. This Glitch May Explain Why.
headline.print_headline: Turning Gray: When Busy Stem Cells Tire, Hair Begins to Lose Its Color

abstract: Men and people with severe illnesses were more likely to develop the condition within a year. But the data does not prove that the coronavirus causes diabetes.
snippet: Men and people with severe illnesses were more likely to develop the condition within a year. But the data does not prove that the coronavirus causes diabetes.
lead_paragraph: People infected with the coronavirus were significantly more likely to be diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes within a year of their infection, compared with those who had not been exposed to the virus, researchers in Canada reported on Tuesday.

headline.main: Covid May Increase the Risk of Type 2 Diabetes, Researchers Find
headline.print_headline: People Who Had Covid May Have Higher Risk Of Developing Diabetes

abstract: Mega-constellations built by SpaceX, Amazon and other companies could carry thousands of sensors that could aid research into gamma rays, space weather and other subjects.
snippet: Mega-constellations built by SpaceX, Amazon and other companies could carry thousands of sensors that could aid research into gamma rays, space weather and other subjects.
lead_paragraph: Each night, the stars of the sky compete with thousands of satellites. The number of intruders is only growing as constellations of satellites proliferate, with companies planning to launch orbiters by the tens of thousands to transmit internet and other communications signals back to Earth. Among them are SpaceX, which has already launched thousands of Starlink satellites, and Amazon, which plans to begin its Project Kuiper constellation later this year.

headline.main: Satellites Threaten Astronomy, but a Few Scientists See an Opportunity
headline.print_headline: Turning Satellites To Their Advantage

abstract: Scientists assembled 3,000 images from an Emirati orbiter to create the prettiest atlas yet of the red planet.
snippet: Scientists assembled 3,000 images from an Emirati orbiter to create the prettiest atlas yet of the red planet.
lead_paragraph: A new global map of Mars offers a fresh perspective on the planet.

headline.main: New Mars Map Lets You ‘See the Whole Planet at Once'
headline.print_headline: ‘I Had Never Seen Mars Like This'

abstract: Researchers said racial bias was the only explanation for excessive testing of Black mothers at a Pennsylvania health system.
snippet: Researchers said racial bias was the only explanation for excessive testing of Black mothers at a Pennsylvania health system.
lead_paragraph: Hospitals are more likely to give drug tests to Black women delivering babies than white women, regardless of the mother's history of substance use, suggests a new study of a health system in Pennsylvania.

headline.main: Black Pregnant Women Are Tested More Frequently for Drug Use, Study Suggests
headline.print_headline: Study Shows A Racial Bias In Drug Tests At Hospitals

abstract: Some researchers question whether A.I. can be truly intelligent without a body to interact with and learn from the physical world.
snippet: Some researchers question whether A.I. can be truly intelligent without a body to interact with and learn from the physical world.
lead_paragraph: What is the relationship between mind and body?

headline.main: Can Intelligence Be Separated From the Body?
headline.print_headline: Can Intelligence Be Separated From the Body?

abstract: An elephant at the Berlin Zoo can use her trunk to peel bananas, an unusual behavior she engages in only when conditions are ripe.
snippet: An elephant at the Berlin Zoo can use her trunk to peel bananas, an unusual behavior she engages in only when conditions are ripe.
lead_paragraph: Pang Pha is an elephant of discriminating taste. Offer her a yellow or green banana and she will hoover it up whole, peel and all. Proffer a brown banana, and she is likely to turn her long nose up at it, casually tossing it aside.

headline.main: This Elephant Taught Herself to Peel Bananas
headline.print_headline: Elephant in Berlin Taught Herself to Peel Bananas, if the Fruit and Time Are Ripe

abstract: Autism rates in girls have steadily risen in recent years. But as more women are diagnosed in adulthood, some wonder how many girls are still missed.
snippet: Autism rates in girls have steadily risen in recent years. But as more women are diagnosed in adulthood, some wonder how many girls are still missed.
lead_paragraph: Morénike Giwa Onaiwu was shocked when day care providers flagged some concerning behaviors in her daughter, Legacy. The toddler was not responding to her name. She avoided eye contact, didn't talk much and liked playing on her own.

headline.main: More Girls Are Being Diagnosed With Autism
headline.print_headline: More Girls Are Being Diagnosed With Autism

abstract: The last thylacine died in captivity in 1936, but a statistical analysis adds a degree of validity to the survival of small groups of the carnivorous marsupials.
snippet: The last thylacine died in captivity in 1936, but a statistical analysis adds a degree of validity to the survival of small groups of the carnivorous marsupials.
lead_paragraph: Depending on whom you ask, the Tasmanian tiger or thylacine has either been extinct for nearly a century or has been just really good at hiding.

headline.main: New Support for Some Extinct Tasmanian Tiger Sightings
headline.print_headline: When Did Tasmanian Tigers Actually Disappear?

abstract: A new study based on strands of hair found in a Spanish burial cave reveals that humans living about 3,000 years ago used hallucinogens, likely derived from local plants, as part of their rituals.
snippet: A new study based on strands of hair found in a Spanish burial cave reveals that humans living about 3,000 years ago used hallucinogens, likely derived from local plants, as part of their rituals.
lead_paragraph: Bronze Age humans have been credited with a number of civilizational advancements: the invention of irrigation, the wheel, writing systems and the ability to forge weapons and tools from the durable metal that lends the era its name.

headline.main: Tripping in the Bronze Age
headline.print_headline: Scientists See Bronze Age In New Light: It Was Trippy.

abstract: In a study of how animals respond to the unknown, goats and camels, especially those with a lower social position, proved most capable of liberating a snack from a cup.
snippet: In a study of how animals respond to the unknown, goats and camels, especially those with a lower social position, proved most capable of liberating a snack from a cup.
lead_paragraph: Fair or not, goats have not earned a reputation for their problem-solving abilities. Crows and chimpanzees are better known for deftly tackling new and unusual situations, like a snack that requires a tool to reach. But if you hide food in a strange cup and put a lid on it, a goat may find a way, a new study finds. And not just any goat, a team of researchers says. Animals that functioned like outsiders in their social group were best at tackling and solving a problem.

headline.main: Outsiders Solve Problems. Just Ask Goats.
headline.print_headline: Mammalian MacGYVERS; Revenge of the Outsiders: Shunned Goats Solve Problems

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)

abstract: The review found that the methodology of many previous studies was flawed and that risk of myriad health problems increased significantly after less than two drinks a day for women and after three for men.
snippet: The review found that the methodology of many previous studies was flawed and that risk of myriad health problems increased significantly after less than two drinks a day for women and after three for men.
lead_paragraph: For decades, scientific studies suggested moderate drinking was better for most people's health than not drinking at all, and could even help them live longer.

headline.main: Moderate Drinking Has No Health Benefits, Analysis of Decades of Research Finds
headline.print_headline: No Benefits To Alcohol, Study Finds

abstract: The spread of the Ebola-like virus has claimed lives but could be a crucial chance to test a vaccine — if supplies and researchers are mobilized in time.
snippet: The spread of the Ebola-like virus has claimed lives but could be a crucial chance to test a vaccine — if supplies and researchers are mobilized in time.
lead_paragraph: Two concurrent outbreaks of the Marburg virus, a close cousin of Ebola that can kill as many as 90 percent of the people it infects, are raising critical questions about the behavior of this mysterious bat-borne pathogen and global efforts to prepare for potential pandemics.

headline.main: New Marburg Outbreaks in Africa Raise Alarm About the Deadly Virus's Spread
headline.print_headline: New Outbreaks in Africa Raise Alarms About Marburg, a Deadly Cousin of Ebola

abstract: The apex dinosaur's terrifying teeth were sheathed in lip-like tissue, some paleontologists say. Imagine them more akin to Komodo dragons than crocodiles.
snippet: The apex dinosaur's terrifying teeth were sheathed in lip-like tissue, some paleontologists say. Imagine them more akin to Komodo dragons than crocodiles.
lead_paragraph: Brimming with serrated teeth bigger than bananas, Tyrannosaurus rex's fanged maw is iconic. Many depictions of the prehistoric predator show its teeth sticking out even when its mouth is closed, like a snaggletoothed crocodile.

headline.main: Imagine T. Rex. Now Imagine It With Lips.
headline.print_headline: Dinosaur Depictions; They Want to Give T. Rex Some Lip

abstract: Scientists recorded the popping noises that plants make in response to stresses like dehydration or a cut.
snippet: Scientists recorded the popping noises that plants make in response to stresses like dehydration or a cut.
lead_paragraph: Humans have glorious ways of vocalizing discontent: We grumble, grouse, gripe, groan, moan. One might think airing complaints requires, at the very least, a mouth. But recent research from the plant kingdom shows that a mouth isn't essential.

headline.main: This Is What It Sounds Like When Plants Cry
headline.print_headline: Distress Signals: Even Potted Plants Aren't Shy About Airing Their Complaints

abstract: A new analysis examined deaths in Britain, where the company's product was restricted in 2021 because of safety concerns.
snippet: A new analysis examined deaths in Britain, where the company's product was restricted in 2021 because of safety concerns.
lead_paragraph: Young women who received at least one dose of the Covid vaccine made by AstraZeneca might have been more likely to die of a heart problem in the 12 weeks after their vaccination, according to an analysis of immunization and death records in Britain released on Monday.

headline.main: AstraZeneca's Covid Vaccine May Have Posed a Higher Heart Risk for Young Women, Study Shows
headline.print_headline: Study Raises Concern on Covid Vaccine Used Outside U.S.

abstract: A genetic analysis of dozens of ancient skeletons from East Africa helps pin down the origins of coastal Swahili society.
snippet: A genetic analysis of dozens of ancient skeletons from East Africa helps pin down the origins of coastal Swahili society.
lead_paragraph: A long history of mercantile trade along the eastern shores of Africa left its mark on the DNA of ancient Swahili people.

headline.main: DNA Confirms Oral History of Swahili People
headline.print_headline: DNA Confirms Oral History of the Swahili People

abstract: Evolution has saved roach reproduction from an earlier mutation that interfered with how males court females.
snippet: Evolution has saved roach reproduction from an earlier mutation that interfered with how males court females.
lead_paragraph: Cockroaches are changing up their sex lives, and it's all our fault. Faced with sweet poisoned bait, roaches first ended up with a mutation that made them hate sweets, hindering their mating strategies. Now, more roach mutations are emerging, showing you can't keep a good pest down.

headline.main: Cockroach Sex Took a Strange Turn. Now More Mutations Have Emerged.
headline.print_headline: Sweet as Sugar; Cockroaches Weren't in the Mood,  So Evolution Came to the Rescue

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)

abstract: Hospitalizations for pediatric suicidal behavior increased by 163 percent over an 11-year period, an analysis of millions of hospital admissions in the United States found.
snippet: Hospitalizations for pediatric suicidal behavior increased by 163 percent over an 11-year period, an analysis of millions of hospital admissions in the United States found.
lead_paragraph: The portion of American hospital beds occupied by children with suicidal or self-harming behavior has soared over the course of a decade, a large study of admissions to acute care hospitals shows.

headline.main: Hospitals Are Increasingly Crowded With Kids Who Tried to Harm Themselves, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Hospitals See a Spike in Children Who Tried to Harm Themselves, a Study Finds

abstract: Brazilian researchers captured on camera the brief moment when lightning rods on buildings released an upward discharge to attract incoming lightning.
snippet: Brazilian researchers captured on camera the brief moment when lightning rods on buildings released an upward discharge to attract incoming lightning.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Franklin invented lightning rods in the 18th century, and the devices have been protecting buildings and people from the destructive forces of lightning ever since. But the details of how lightning rods function are still the subject of scientific research.

headline.main: One of the Luckiest Lightning Strikes Ever Recorded
headline.print_headline: Upward Mobility: Why Lightning Rods Just Can't Wait for Lightning to Strike

abstract: And it all began with a hobbyist “messing about and experimenting with shapes.”
snippet: And it all began with a hobbyist “messing about and experimenting with shapes.”
lead_paragraph: Last November, after a decade of failed attempts, David Smith, a self-described shape hobbyist of Bridlington in East Yorkshire, England, suspected that he might have finally solved an open problem in the mathematics of tiling: That is, he thought he might have discovered an “einstein.”

headline.main: Elusive ‘Einstein' Solves a Longstanding Math Problem
headline.print_headline: This ‘Einstein' Was a Math Puzzle to Be Solved

abstract: Some researchers claim that chatbots have developed theory of mind. But is that just our own theory of mind gone wild?
snippet: Some researchers claim that chatbots have developed theory of mind. But is that just our own theory of mind gone wild?
lead_paragraph: Mind reading is common among us humans. Not in the ways that psychics claim to do it, by gaining access to the warm streams of consciousness that fill every individual's experience, or in the ways that mentalists claim to do it, by pulling a thought out of your head at will. Everyday mind reading is more subtle: We take in people's faces and movements, listen to their words and then decide or intuit what might be going on in their heads.

headline.main: Can a Machine Know That We Know What It Knows?
headline.print_headline: Human Power to Process Cues May Be Next Frontier for Bots

abstract: While live bees can be used as a deterrent to keep elephants away from farms, a new technology fills in for cases where a buzz without the sting is preferable.
snippet: While live bees can be used as a deterrent to keep elephants away from farms, a new technology fills in for cases where a buzz without the sting is preferable.
lead_paragraph: It's a familiar, dreaded scenario in many parts of Africa and Asia: An elephant shows up, wanders into farmers' fields, and tramples and eats crops. Sometimes farmers fight back, and elephants are killed.

headline.main: A Sting Operation to Save Elephants, With No Stings
headline.print_headline: To Save Elephants: All Buzz, No Kill

abstract: Forty-one bent or twisted iron nails, unearthed from a second-century imperial burial site, were meant to keep the deceased in their place.
snippet: Forty-one bent or twisted iron nails, unearthed from a second-century imperial burial site, were meant to keep the deceased in their place.
lead_paragraph: When it came to the treatment of diseases, the ancient Romans had no shortage of magical remedies, several of which involved iron nails. To cure epilepsy, the first-century historian Pliny the Elder advised driving a nail into the ground at the spot where the afflicted person's head lay at the start of the seizure. The Romans hammered nails into doors to avert plagues and pounded coffin nails into thresholds to keep nightmares at bay. Nails from tombs and crucifixions were sometimes even worn around the neck as talismans against fevers, malaria and evil spells.

headline.main: In a Roman Tomb, ‘Dead Nails' Reveal an Occult Practice
headline.print_headline: ‘Death Nails' in Tomb Reveal Occult Practice

abstract: Scientists have retracted a study that showed a rare goblin shark washed up on a Greek beach after other researchers voiced doubts about the find.
snippet: Scientists have retracted a study that showed a rare goblin shark washed up on a Greek beach after other researchers voiced doubts about the find.
lead_paragraph: Goblin sharks are deep-sea fish whose frightening, protrusile jaws served as an inspiration for the terrifying creatures in the “Alien” movie franchise. Little is known about these elusive sharks, and sightings of them are extraordinarily rare. They are known to live in deep coastal waters all over the world but have never been found in the Mediterranean Sea.

headline.main: A Shark Discovery ‘Didn't Look Right.' It Might Have Been a Plastic Toy.
headline.print_headline: Shark Researchers Took the Bait

abstract: A pair of images, taken eight years apart, show changes to the ice giant planet as spring arrives in the northern hemisphere.
snippet: A pair of images, taken eight years apart, show changes to the ice giant planet as spring arrives in the northern hemisphere.
lead_paragraph: With the passage of the vernal equinox a few days ago, we in the Northern Hemisphere can look forward to the warmer days of spring while those in the Southern Hemisphere will begin to feel the chill of autumn.

headline.main: A Paler Uranus Emerges in the Latest Hubble Telescope Image
headline.print_headline: Slow-Motion Seasons: Icy Planet Starts to Show A Lighter Shade of Pale

abstract: A new analysis summarizes the emerging picture of factors that make long-term post-Covid symptoms more likely.
snippet: A new analysis summarizes the emerging picture of factors that make long-term post-Covid symptoms more likely.
lead_paragraph: Which coronavirus patients are most at risk for developing long Covid?

headline.main: Who Is Most at Risk for Long Covid?
headline.print_headline: Analysis Reveals the Biggest Risk Factors for Long Covid

abstract: By analyzing seven samples of hair said to have come from Ludwig van Beethoven, researchers debunked myths about the revered composer while raising new questions about his life and death.
snippet: By analyzing seven samples of hair said to have come from Ludwig van Beethoven, researchers debunked myths about the revered composer while raising new questions about his life and death.
lead_paragraph: It was March 1827 and Ludwig van Beethoven was dying. As he lay in bed, wracked with abdominal pain and jaundiced, grieving friends and acquaintances came to visit. And some asked a favor: Could they clip a lock of his hair for remembrance?

headline.main: DNA From Beethoven's Hair Unlocks Medical and Family Secrets

lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans who are at high risk for heart attacks and whose LDL cholesterol levels are disturbingly high have been told over and over again by their doctors to take a statin. lead_paragraph: With a bite that could split a shark in two and an armored mug only a mother could love, Dunkleosteus was one of Earth's earliest apex predators, terrorizing subtropical seas 360 million years ago during the Devonian Period. lead_paragraph: At its best, paleontology opens windows into trillions of other lifetimes spent swimming, scuttling, stomping and soaring across this planet. abstract: Fossils found in New Zealand highlight an era after the dinosaurs when giant flightless birds prowled the seas for prey.
snippet: Fossils found in New Zealand highlight an era after the dinosaurs when giant flightless birds prowled the seas for prey.
lead_paragraph: New Zealand has been a haven for earthbound birds for eons. The absence of terrestrial predators allowed flightless parrots, kiwis and moas to thrive. Now researchers are adding two prehistoric penguins to this grounded aviary. One species is a beefy behemoth that waddled along the New Zealand coastline nearly 60 million years ago. At almost 350 pounds, it weighed as much as an adult gorilla and is the heaviest penguin known to science.

headline.main: The Biggest Penguin That Ever Existed Was a ‘Monster Bird'
headline.print_headline: Heavy Waddler: Sixty Million Years Ago, a Penguin the Size of an Offensive Lineman

abstract: A maternal preference for sons in a group of killer whales that swim off the Pacific Northwest may contribute to its endangered status.
snippet: A maternal preference for sons in a group of killer whales that swim off the Pacific Northwest may contribute to its endangered status.
lead_paragraph: A fully grown male orca is one of the planet's fiercest hunters. He's a wily, streamlined torpedo who can weigh as much as 11 tons. No other animal preys on him. Yet in at least one population, these apex predators struggle to survive without their moms, who catch their food and even cut it up for them.

headline.main: Orca Moms Pay a High Price to Feed Large Adult Sons
headline.print_headline: Mooching Sons Sap Orca Moms

abstract: Researchers said the paleontological remains were another sign that our early human cousins had intelligence.
snippet: Researchers said the paleontological remains were another sign that our early human cousins had intelligence.
lead_paragraph: A number of cities vie for the unofficial title of “seafood capital of the world,” and Lisbon has a good claim. The city, Portugal's coastal capital, is famous for its salted cod, sardines and stuffed brown crab. A study published Tuesday in the journal Frontiers in Environmental Archaeology reveals that these brown crabs have been on the menu for a long time. In a cave less than 20 miles from Lisbon, researchers discovered charred remnants of shells and claws: evidence that Neanderthals were cooking and eating crab 90,000 years ago.

headline.main: Neanderthal Crab Roast Leftovers Are Found in a Portuguese Cave
headline.print_headline: Seafood Lovers: Found in a Portuguese Cave, Signs of a Neanderthal Crab Roast

abstract: The research illustrates how much scientists still have to learn about a molecule as simple as water.
snippet: The research illustrates how much scientists still have to learn about a molecule as simple as water.
lead_paragraph: Shaken and chilled — but not stirred — ordinary frozen water turns into something different: a newly discovered form of ice made of a jumble of molecules with unique properties.

headline.main: Shaking Ordinary Ice (Very Hard) Transformed It Into Something Never Seen Before
headline.print_headline: Shake Ice Hard Enough, And It Turns Unearthly

abstract: Experiments suggested that when bears rub against tree bark, they may be trying to do more than scratch an itch or mark territory.
snippet: Experiments suggested that when bears rub against tree bark, they may be trying to do more than scratch an itch or mark territory.
lead_paragraph: There are many reasons bears shimmy and scratch against trees. Sometimes they communicate by scent-marking trees, other times they're removing hair and scratching that hard-to-reach itch. A new study posits an additional perk: slathering on nature-made tick repellent.

headline.main: Why Do Bears Rub Against Trees? Scientists Offer New Explanation.
headline.print_headline: Ticked Off: Why Do Bears Rub Against Trees? That's a Real Head-Scratcher.

abstract: In her youth, Blue was a standout mine-hunter for the U.S. military. She and her colleagues are now at the vanguard of geriatric marine mammal medicine.
snippet: In her youth, Blue was a standout mine-hunter for the U.S. military. She and her colleagues are now at the vanguard of geriatric marine mammal medicine.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — White caps were breaking in the bay and the rain was blowing sideways, but at Naval Base Point Loma, an elderly bottlenose dolphin named Blue was absolutely not acting her age. In a bay full of dolphins, she was impossible to miss, leaping from the water and whistling as a team of veterinarians approached along the floating docks.

headline.main: The Navy's Dolphins Have a Few Things to Tell Us About Aging
headline.print_headline: A Life of Service

lead_paragraph: Every summer in waters off the town of Laguna in Brazil's southeast corner, fishers wade out into estuary canals to cast their nets in hopes of catching migratory mullet fish. The water is murky, and the fish are difficult to spot. However, the fishers have help from an unexpected quarter: bottlenose dolphins that push the prey toward the nets.

abstract: The submarine-size ocean creatures were not always behemoths. Now, a new study has found that the secret to a whale's size may be in its genes.
snippet: The submarine-size ocean creatures were not always behemoths. Now, a new study has found that the secret to a whale's size may be in its genes.
lead_paragraph: With names like titanosaurus and giganotosaurus, you'd be forgiven for thinking that dinosaurs were the most massive animals to ever live. But if you're after gargantuan creatures, chartering a boat is better than building a time machine — the largest animals to ever exist are whales, topped off by the truly titanic blue whale. Maxing out at almost 100 feet long and 190 metric tons, the blue whale dwarfs the competition.

headline.main: Unlocking the Genes That Made Whales Into Giants
headline.print_headline: Wee Whales: When Jonah Would Have Been A Little Too Much to Swallow

lead_paragraph: Consider the oyster mushroom. It's a mild thing, a pert, often creamy-colored whorl of fungus that goes well with thyme sautéed in butter. But among scientists who study mushrooms, it has earned a reputation for activities more sinister than you'd expect from a fungus found in fine dining. The oyster mushroom is a carnivore.

headline.main: The Toxin That Helps Oyster Mushrooms Devour Worm Flesh

lead_paragraph: Walliserops trifurcatus wasn't like the other trilobites. Sure, it had a body like a cross between a pillbug and a horseshoe crab. But it also wielded an immense, flat-bladed trident, projecting from its front like an oversize hood ornament and conjuring the three-tipped tool of the Greek god Poseidon (known to the Romans as Neptune).

headline.main: Why This Trilobite Had Neptune's Trident for a Nose

lead_paragraph: At first glance, you might miss the glass frog of the Costa Rican rainforest. It is, as the name suggests, nearly transparent. The lager, as the new beer was called, had begun its journey to world domination.

lead_paragraph: To ward off supersized predators, many herbivorous dinosaurs were biologically armed to the teeth. Some had skulls studded with horns, while others had tails bristling with spikes. But few matched the arsenal of ankylosaurs, a group of herbivores that peaked in diversity during the Cretaceous period. Most of the ankylosaur's body was encased in bony plates that jutted out into jagged points, and some lugged around a sledgehammer-like tail club capable of delivering a bone-cracking blow.

headline.main: The Ankylosaur's Tail-Club Wasn't Only Swinging at T. Rex
headline.print_headline: Angry Ankylosaurs: A Sledgehammer for a Tail, And a Host of Rivals to Pound

lead_paragraph: Anyone who's had a shady oyster or a mushroom soup that didn't sit well remembers the ominous queasiness heralding impending bad times. Bacteria release toxins that start the body's process of speedily evacuating the contents of the stomach. It's a protective mechanism of sorts — getting rid of the invaders en masse is probably helpful in the long term, even if it's unpleasant in the short. But it has remained something of a mystery how the brain gets the alarm signal, then sends another one to tell the stomach to initiate a technicolor yawn.

abstract: With a one-of-a-kind museum specimen, researchers recreated the chirp of ancient cricket relatives that droned alongside the dinosaurs.

lead_paragraph: Whether it's a cicada's earsplitting drone, a bee's blaring buzz or a cricket's incessant chirp, insects are a staple of summer's score. And arthropods have been making a racket for hundreds of millions of years. One of the noisier groups has been the Prophalangopsidae, a suite of singing insects that went mainstream during the Jurassic period when some 100 species clamored about. While related to modern crickets and katydids, these ancient arthropods left few direct descendants, making it difficult to decipher what these Mesozoic maestros sounded like.

headline.main: Modern and Ancient Crickets May Sing the Same Song

Relatives of sea horses and pipefish, sea dragons have long narrow snouts that they use like a straw to suck up meals of microscopic crustaceans. Instead of scales, the fish are covered in bony armor, and their backbones are kinked. Like their sea horse cousins, male sea dragons  gestate a female's fertilized eggs in a pouch.

He opened the lid of a nest box for western pygmy possums at the Monjebup Nature Reserve, which his organization manages in southwestern Australia. There, among the leaves, he found not just a family of pygmy possums, but also a small, orange-eyed lizard known as a western spiny-tailed gecko.

lead_paragraph: Dementia cases are climbing along with an aging world population, and yet another much-anticipated Alzheimer's medication, crenezumab, has proved ineffective in clinical trials — the latest of many disappointments. Public health experts and researchers argue that it is past time to turn our attention to a different approach — focusing on eliminating a dozen or so already known risk factors, like untreated high blood pressure, hearing loss and smoking, rather than on an exorbitantly priced, whiz-bang new drug.

headline.main: New Dementia Prevention Method May Be Behavioral, Not Prescribed

However, turtles and tortoises age more gracefully. Despite their wrinkled skin and toothless gums, species like Galápagos giant tortoises seem unscathed by the ravages of aging. Some show few signs of slowing down as they plod into their 100s.

lead_paragraph: As the days of summer pass, the antlers get longer on moose, elk and other animals in the cervid, or deer, family. The animals spend most of the summer grazing, their head weaponry sheathed in fuzzy velvet. But by the start of autumn, the antlers will be ready for action as male suitors gather to posture, preen and butt heads — a behavior that some people may have in mind when they use the phrase “locking horns.”

abstract: A new study found that primeval rodents, which were estimated to be the size of bison, were closer to modern-day ponies.
snippet: A new study found that primeval rodents, which were estimated to be the size of bison, were closer to modern-day ponies.
lead_paragraph: Modern rodents range in size from pygmy mice weighing less than an ounce to stocky capybaras pushing 175 pounds. But even the largest capybara is a pipsqueak compared with some prehistoric rodents that resembled a cross between a supersized capybara and a hairy hippopotamus. Paleontologists estimate that one, Phoberomys pattersoni, may have weighed as much as 1,300 pounds. Another, Josephoartigasia monesi, was believed to be around 2,000 pounds, as big as a bison.

headline.main: Earth's Largest Rodents Were Smaller Than We Once Thought

abstract: Evolutionary theories said giraffes developed their height to get to better eats, but ancestors may have gained the advantage through head-butting battles.

By the fourth day or so after consumption, your liver and kidneys begin to fail. After about a week, you may well die.
